This is probably not the right choice. It would be better to have a random field in auto generated job name. Because Dataflow service does not accept two jobs with the same name at the same time, job_name-time combination will be unique already.
Ah didn't know about that. I'll close this.

@bjchambers split the factory into 2 classes and renamed namespaces as discussed.
PTAL
This PR LGTM as is. Are you planning to make any more changes in this PR?
No the two changes we discussed seem unrelated so I can do them in separate PRs.

R: @lukecwik
LGTM (I'll merge this), do you want to do a follow up change so that a user can also specify the charset when writing as well?
Yes, let me add the write part in a new commit.
Great
My belief is that this was explicitly omitted because XMLIO is not actually correct with most charsets. How can you guard against bugs from users paramterizing with bad charsets here?
Only the javadoc comment that states that we don't support multi byte encodings.

The extra overhead mentioned above for ``SimpleInvoker`` seems to be due process invocation of ``DoFnRunner`` now involving calling a method of a ``DoFnInvoker`` object instead of directly invoking a cached process method. (overhead of doing ``invoker.invoke_process()`` instead of ``process()``). To remove this overhead we'll have to remove modularity of invocation logic introduced by this CL. I don't think the amount of overhead observed in Robert's benchmark (0.1 sec per 10k invocations of process() method) justify totally removing modularity/structure of our DoFn invocation logic. Robert WDYT ?
Hey @markflyhigh, do you still need this PR open?

R: @kennknowles @dhalperi

@lukecwik I think there's a plausible case for dropping `ByteKey`, but I think this PR is a strict improvement over the existing code that depends on Protobuf. I'd propose reviewing as an improvement and deferring decision to drop ByteKey elsewhere.

(Personally, I see your point, but think it's a prohibitively complex API change for the stuff we're doing this week.)
Jenkins is still down, and the travis Java tests are perma-red, but the Python ones are passing. Merging.

LGTM
We can add it to the if we got time before first stable release bucket.
@jasonkuster @davorbonaci Could we disable the Java tests in Travis? The tests are permared, but Python tests are still providing a useful signal.

Coverage decreased (-0.02%) to 70.026% when pulling **f2c19084f94cf81a9702b33fc57febe88a28b975 on robertwb:gen-protos** into **f8d6168167b133d2c5279d92963294ad2733e9bb on apache:master**.
Should we actually pin all dependencies? We make the assumption that our dependencies would not introduce breaking changes without a major version change but it happens frequently.

I don't have strong opinions around this but here are some of my thoughts:

1. We can upgrade at our own pace and can always promise that beam head is stable.

2. Having really strict version pinning makes it hard for users of Beam to always make sure they are using the same versions of the library. So if a user was already using a higher version than us for a library that made safe changes, it'll be annoying for them but I guess if we generally stay up to date with latest versions very few ppl will have that issue.
Might be worthwhile exploring some sort of version-eye style system to make sure we're upgrading on time.
Robert, PTAL.
Your have valid points. Then at release time we need to ensure that corresponding pieces (e.q. dataflow container) has at least the minimum version of all referenced dependencies.
LGTM
Thanks

@JingsongLi Thanks for working on this! 😃 

I did some small refactorings. Among other things, the base for Flink combine runners is now `AbstractFlinkCombineRunner` and there is a `SortingFlinkCombineRunner` and a `HashingFlinkCombineRunner`.  I hope that's alright.
